comments:
This course will provide an introduction to community health nursing in the context of the public health paradigm. Through a series of lectures and discussions, students will identify applications of the public health paradigm to community-based nursing practice with individuals, families, and populations. Topics include the history of public health, the core public health sciences, environmental and occupational health, oral health, global health and the social determinants of health, health promotion, as well as prevention and intervention approaches to chronic and infectious diseases and injuries.

This course overall helped students to become more interested in community health. However, students often felt that the information, although informative, was not particularly practical to their nursing skills. One student remarked that it was “nice to learn about issues from a broader” perspective. But some students felt that the course is better positioned in the sophomore year.

Professor Lewis was described as “a very sweet, warm and nice person” who provided “relevant research to show evidence of how things work or don’t work.” Students said that Professor Lewis sometimes read off of her slides. Overall, though, most students felt Professor Lewis was approachable and available to help students whenever needed.

The class is a requirement for seniors in the nursing school and the grades are determined by two exams and a project. Students warned that there was not a wealth of testable materials in lectures. Many students thought the exams were poorly written and consisted of vague questions. Some individuals suggested having a take-home exam. The pre-requisite courses are NURS 210, 220, 240, 270, 321, 322 and the co-requisite course is NURS341.

This course will provide an introduction to community health nursing in the context of the public health paradigm. Through a series of lectures and discussions, students will identify applications of the public health paradigm to community-based nursing practice with individuals, families, and populations. Topics include the history of public health, the core public health sciences, environmental and occupational health, oral health, global health and the social determinants of health, health promotion, as well as prevention and intervention approaches to chronic and infectious diseases and injuries.

This course overall helped students to become more interested in community health. However, students often felt that the information, although informative, was not particularly practical to their nursing skills. One student remarked that it was “nice to learn about issues from a broader” perspective. But some students felt that the course is better positioned in the sophomore year.

Professor Bonaduce was “accommodating, knowledgeable, and helpful.” But most students did not appreciate Professor Bonaduce’s personal stories during class. Though, one student stated that “Professor Bonaduce was excellent and was so willing to work with students and their specific needs.”

The class is a requirement for seniors in the nursing school and the grades are determined by two exams and a project. Students warned that there was not a wealth of testable materials in lectures. Many students thought the exams were poorly written and consisted of vague questions. Some individuals suggested having a take-home exam. The pre-requisite courses are NURS 210, 220, 240, 270, 321, 322 and the co-requisite course is NURS341.

This course will provide an introduction to community health nursing in the context of the public health paradigm. Through a series of lectures and discussions, students will identify applications of the public health paradigm to community-based nursing practice with individuals, families, and populations. Topics include the history of public health, the core public health sciences, environmental and occupational health, oral health, global health and the social determinants of health, health promotion, as well as prevention and intervention approaches to chronic and infectious diseases and injuries.

This course overall helped students to become more interested in community health. However, students often felt that the information, although informative, was not particularly practical to their nursing skills. One student remarked that it was “nice to learn about issues from a broader” perspective. But some students felt that the course is better positioned in the sophomore year.

Professor McHugh, in the words of one student, “is clearly very smart.” The lectures provided by Professor McHugh were described as somewhat juvenile in content and did not do the topic justice. One student suggested that Professor McHugh make the classes more interactive to better understand the application of the information to practice.

The class is a requirement for seniors in the nursing school and the grades are determined by two exams and a project. Students warned that there was not a wealth of testable materials in lectures. Many students thought the exams were poorly written and consisted of vague questions. Some individuals suggested having a take-home exam. The pre-requisite courses are NURS 210, 220, 240, 270, 321, 322 and the co-requisite course is NURS341.
